text: I've got a file upload field in a form, where users can upload an image. It seems like printing this contact property results in a signed redirect url. Is there any way to print this property on a page and get the real image url?

Hey <@U3A4KEWK1> You’ll have to upload these to the file manager after the upload to get a publicly available URL. This is because we make the assumption that anything submitted via a form is private. Since this is a relatively common ask, we do have some example apps in various languages, what language are you working in?
Uh, just HubL
And javascript and stuff
ah, this will need serverside code so not possible in that case
I suppose it's probably not possible to do with a workflow
Not directly, you may be able to send a webhook to a lambda function though as the simplest way to host some server side code
Where can I see the example apps?

Node: <https://github.com/HubSpot/integration-examples-nodejs/tree/master/form-file-submission-access-app>
PHP: <https://github.com/HubSpot/integration-examples-php/tree/master/form-submission-file-download-app>
Ruby: <https://github.com/HubSpot/integration-examples-ruby/tree/master/form-submission-file-download-app>
Thanks!
<@U54TVT3C1> How well does the file upload field work in general? Have you run into any limitations other than the one you described above?

Nope. That is for content only - creating pages from existing templates and styles. I was hoping there is a "staging" area for development where you can add new page templates, add to existing page templates without touching the live site.
Anyone have any recommendations for a freelance designer with a strong understanding or knowledge of UX
Out of curiosity, what custom action were you looking to add here?
Does anyone have any experience personalizing pages based on a cookie?
Wondering if there’s any way to set custom personalization tokens

<@U54TVT3C1> this works:
```{% if request.cookies.the_cookie_name == "the cookie value" %}
show me only if the user has this cookie key/value!
{% endif %}```
downside is it will disable the page cache
Ah.  I think that’s a sacrifice I’m willing to make.  This should be fun to make marketer friendly
or, of course, you could just print the cookie value like `{{ request.cookies.the_cookie_name }}`
:thumbsup:
I’m still very much in the theoretical stage of this, but this is some good advice.
i've used it on a production site, set the cookie with javascript on click of a link and the page loads the "personalization token" instantly, it's definitely got it's pros
The trials and tribulations of using HubSpot CMS and Pardot for marketing automation
Normally, I’d just do this with a contact property, but I’m going to have to get a little more creative this way.
We’re going to cookie users when they login to our software platform and then customize their experience based on that
